soft_skills.name: Intellectual Curiosity
soft_skills.description: Essential for understanding new scientific domains and fostering innovation.

questions.question: Intellectual curiosity is essential for understanding new scientific domains and fostering innovation.
What is the key element of intellectual curiosity?
What is the topic you are least curious about intellectually?

soft_skills.name: Analytical Thinking
soft_skills.description: Allows solving complex problems by examining different perspectives and interpreting data with rigor.

questions.question: Analytical thinking allows you to solve complex problems by examining different perspectives and interpreting data with rigor.
What is the main goal of analytical thinking in scientific research?
options: Following outdated methods without questioning them

questions.question: What tools or methods do you use to assess the reliability of the information you analyze in your research?

soft_skills.name: Scientific Rigor
soft_skills.description: Involves following precise protocols and carefully documenting each step of an experiment.

questions.question: Scientific rigor involves following precise protocols and carefully documenting each step of an experiment.
What characterizes scientific rigor?
options: Using a systematic and verifiable method

questions.question: In your opinion, what best defines scientific rigor in the world around you?

soft_skills.name: Critical Thinking
soft_skills.description: Involves questioning assumptions, evidence, and arguments critically.

questions.question: Critical thinking means accepting ideas as they are presented without questioning them.
What is the most important aspect of critical thinking?
How do you apply critical thinking when a colleague proposes a theory that seems poorly supported?

soft_skills.name: Scientific Creativity
soft_skills.description: Relies on innovating and exploring solutions to complex problems.

questions.question: Scientific creativity relies solely on inventing new technologies without considering traditional methods.
What is the main way scientific creativity can solve complex problems?
options: Applying the same proven solutions to every problem
Exploring innovative solutions that haven’t been tried yet
Following strict protocols without deviating from established methods

questions.question: What approaches do you use to stimulate your scientific creativity when a project feels too routine?

soft_skills.name: Scientific Project Management
soft_skills.description: Involves planning, coordinating, and executing projects while meeting deadlines and budgets.

questions.question: Scientific project management involves planning, coordinating, and executing projects while meeting deadlines and budgets.
What is an essential aspect of scientific project management?
options: Focusing only on the final results
Deciding which TV series to watch during breaks

questions.question: In a scientific project, what do you consider the first priority?

soft_skills.name: Data-Driven Decision Making
soft_skills.description: Relies on empirical data to guide decisions in a scientific environment.

questions.question: Decision-making in a scientific environment primarily relies on intuition rather than empirical data.
When is it most relevant to make a decision based on data in scientific research?
options: When personal intuition seems more reliable

questions.question: What types of data-driven decisions would you make if given the opportunity?

soft_skills.name: Modeling and Simulation Skills
soft_skills.description: Use models and simulations to test hypotheses and predict outcomes.

questions.question: Modeling and simulation skills are only useful for researchers in computer science and mathematics.
In which field are modeling and simulation skills crucial?
How would you use modeling and simulation to test hypotheses or predict outcomes in your research?

soft_skills.name: Scientific Teamwork
soft_skills.description: Relies on collaboration and sharing ideas among researchers.

questions.question: Scientific teamwork relies on collaboration and sharing ideas between researchers, which is crucial for advancing a research project.
What is the main characteristic of good teamwork in scientific research?
options: Sharing information and working together toward a common goal

questions.question: How would you organize collaboration within a research team, especially when there are differing opinions?

soft_skills.name: Adaptability to New Technologies
soft_skills.description: Allows integration of innovations to improve research methods.

questions.question: Adaptability to new technologies is an asset in science because it allows the integration of innovations to improve research methods.
Why is it important to adapt to new technologies in scientific research?
options: To focus only on theoretical aspects

questions.question: What technology do you believe is the most useful in various scientific research areas, and why?

soft_skills.name: Clear Scientific Communication
soft_skills.description: Crucial for sharing discoveries with a broader audience, whether scientific or not.

questions.question: Clear scientific communication is crucial for sharing discoveries with a broader audience, whether scientific or not.
What is the main characteristic of clear scientific communication?
options: Using complex jargon to impress your children
Making concepts accessible to a broad audience

questions.question: How do you ensure your research is understandable to a non-specialist audience?

soft_skills.name: Managing Uncertainty
soft_skills.description: Important in science because experiment results can sometimes be unpredictable or contradictory.

questions.question: Managing uncertainty is important in science because experiment results can sometimes be unpredictable or contradictory.
How do you manage uncertainty in your scientific research?
options: Abandoning research as soon as results are uncertain

questions.question: What approach do you take when confronted with unexpected or uncertain results in an experiment, regardless of the field?

soft_skills.name: Interdisciplinary Collaboration
soft_skills.description: Allows tackling a problem from multiple angles and combining varied skill sets.

questions.question: Interdisciplinary collaboration is beneficial in science because it allows tackling a problem from multiple angles and combining varied skill sets.
What is the main strength of interdisciplinary collaboration in scientific research?
options: Combining different skills and expertise to solve complex problems

questions.question: Are there two fields where collaboration seems impossible?

soft_skills.name: Managing Scientific Failure
soft_skills.description: Involves analyzing errors, learning from them, and adjusting the approach.

questions.question: Managing scientific failure involves abandoning a project when it encounters significant difficulties.
What does managing a scientific failure well mean?
options: Not getting depressed after making a mistake
Analyzing errors, learning from them, and adjusting the approach
Ignoring failure and continuing as if nothing happened

questions.question: What, in your opinion, would be the worst failure for a scientist?

soft_skills.name: Precision in Experimentation
soft_skills.description: Essential for obtaining reliable and reproducible results.

questions.question: Precision in experimentation is essential for obtaining reliable and reproducible results.
Why is precision crucial in scientific experiments?
options: To ensure that results are reproducible and valid

questions.question: For which scientific experiment would you be willing to be a test subject?

soft_skills.name: Ability to Defend a Hypothesis
soft_skills.description: Requires demonstrating validation through experimental results and evidence.

questions.question: Defending a scientific hypothesis requires demonstrating that it is validated by experimental results and evidence.
What is the first step in defending a scientific hypothesis?
options: Building a strong argument based on experimental evidence
Raising your right hand and swearing to tell only the truth
Rejecting any contradictory hypothesis without evidence

questions.question: What area of science are you most knowledgeable about, and can you share an anecdote related to this field?

soft_skills.name: Scientific Ethics
soft_skills.description: Involves transparency, integrity, and considering the societal impact of research.

questions.question: Scientific ethics only involves following experimental protocols without considering the societal impact of research.
What is a fundamental aspect of scientific ethics?
options: Manipulating results to match the hypothesis
Ensuring transparency and integrity in scientific data
Ignoring moral questions related to research

questions.question: What would you do if you discovered that a colleague manipulated or falsified data in a joint research project?

soft_skills.name: Autonomous Learning
soft_skills.description: A way to stay updated in one's scientific field without needing formal training.

questions.question: Autonomous learning is a way to stay updated in one's scientific field without needing formal training.
What is the key to autonomous learning in science?
options: Waiting for others to share their knowledge
Actively seeking out resources to deepen your understanding

questions.question: How do you organize your autonomous learning to stay updated in your field of expertise?

soft_skills.name: Managing Complexity
soft_skills.description: Involves breaking down complex problems into simpler sub-problems to better understand them.

questions.question: Managing complexity in science involves breaking down complex problems into simpler sub-problems to better understand them.
What approach is essential for managing complexity in a scientific project?
options: Not starting scientific projects at all
Tackling each problem globally without breaking it down
Breaking down complex problems into smaller, solvable steps
Focusing solely on theory without practical application

questions.question: If multiple people have different ideas for solving a complicated problem, how do you listen to them and make a decision?

soft_skills.name: Resilience to Criticism
soft_skills.description: Involves accepting feedback and using it to improve one's work.

questions.question: Resilience to criticism involves rejecting others' feedback and continuing to work according to one's own methods.
Why is it important to develop resilience to criticism in science?
options: To continuously improve one's work and learn from feedback
To defend against any form of criticism
To quit immediately after receiving criticism

questions.question: Who, in your opinion, is the best example of resilience to criticism?
